result.markdown: --- title: "Take-home_Ex01" author: "Stefanie Felicia" date: "" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true warning: false freeze: true --- # Background background of what I'm doing and objective of the analysis A local online media company that publishes daily content on digital platforms is planning to release an article on **demographic structures and distribution of Singapore in 2024**. Assuming the role of the graphical editor of the media company, you are tasked to prepare **at most three data visualisation** for the article. # The Data The dataset was extracted from Singstat under the name Singapore Residents by Planning Area / Subzone, Single Year of Age and Sex, June 2024. ![](images/screenshot_dataset.png) It comprised of 6 variables and 60K records. The dataset recorded the demographics and count of residents who lived in each sub zone and planning area in June 2024. # Load Required Libraries ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(dplyr, tidyverse) ``` ::: # Import Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} population_data <- read_csv("respopagesex2024.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 60424 Columns: 6 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (4): PA, SZ, Age, Sex dbl (2): Pop, Time ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: As can be seen above, the data set comprise of 6 variables: 4 variables are character data type (namely, PA, SZ, age and sex), and 2 variables are double data type (number of population, time). Here is the a snippet of the data set: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(population_data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 6 PA SZ Age Sex Pop Time 1 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0 Males 10 2024 2 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0 Females 10 2024 3 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 1 Males 10 2024 4 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 1 Females 10 2024 5 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 2 Males 10 2024 6 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 2 Females 10 2024 ``` ::: ::: # Data pre-processing First, we will look if there are duplicates found in the data set. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} nrow(population_data[duplicated(population_data), ]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: Next, we will check for missing values in the data set. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sapply(population_data, function(x) sum(is.na(x))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` PA SZ Age Sex Pop Time 0 0 0 0 0 0 ``` ::: ::: Column Transformation ::: {.panel-tabset} ## Age Currently, the Age variable is in string data type and we want to change it to numeric data type. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} population_data$Age[population_data$Age == "90_and_Over"] <- "90" typeof(population_data$Age) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} population_data$Age <- as.numeric(population_data$Age) ``` ::: ## Sex We also want to recode the Sex variable from "Males" to 0 and "Females" to 1, why ? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} population_data$Sex[population_data$Sex == "Females"] <- "1" population_data$Sex[population_data$Sex == "Males"] <- "0" population_data$Sex <- as.numeric(population_data$Sex) ``` ::: ::: Univariate ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = population_data, aes(x = Sex)) + geom_bar(color = "grey30", fill = "steelblue") + labs(y = "Count", title = "Count of Records by Sex") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-home_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data=population_data, aes(x = Age)) + geom_histogram(bins=20, color="gray30", fill="cyan3")+ labs(title = "Age Distribution of Singapore Resident June 2024", x = "Age", y = "Count") + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-home_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Variable Selection Age and Gender Distribution of Singapore Residents ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} population_data %>% mutate(population = ifelse(Sex == 0, Pop * (-1), Pop * 1)) %>% ggplot(aes(x = Age, y = population, fill = Sex)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") + coord_flip() + labs(title = "Age-Sex Pyramid", x = "Age", y = "Population") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Take-home_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Population of Residents Living in Each Subzone/Planning Area Demographics of Residents Living in Each Subzone/Planning Area References 1. How to Count Duplicates in R (With Examples)
